real.title: What If My Problems Are Real?
real.description: This article discusses the difference between depression and natural sadness, emphasizing that depression is always linked to distorted thinking, while sadness is a normal response to real events. It clarifies that even serious life problems do not directly cause depression; they affect our emotional state through the filter of our thoughts. Understanding and correcting distorted thoughts can greatly help in coping with depression, separating it from natural sadness brought on by life’s circumstances.

texts: As you read our section on depression or explore the cognitive approach to this condition, you may wonder: “CBT says depression is always tied to distorted thinking—but what if my problems are real?”
You might feel that very real hardships—like the death of a loved one, financial difficulties, debt, bankruptcy, or illness—lead to a “realistic depression.”
We’re not minimizing these hardships—far from it. However, in CBT terms, there is no such thing as a “realistic depression.”
Sometimes we call something depression when it isn’t—confusing the disorder with yearning, sadness, or temporary low mood.
These difficult emotions can be part of a depressive disorder, but there are important differences.

quote.text: People who have never dealt with depression think it’s just being sad or in a bad mood. For me, it’s not depression; it’s slipping into a state of grayness and numbness.
quote.author: Dan Reynolds

texts: The key question is where to draw the line between normal sadness and depression. What’s the difference between “healthy sadness” and true depression?
Sadness is a natural emotion that arises in response to a realistic awareness of loss or disappointment.
For example, when we lose someone close, it’s understandable to feel that life will be painful without them.
These feelings are natural, justified, and even valuable: they help us process events and grow.
Depression, by contrast, is an illness in which distorted thinking plays a central role.

If, in a similar situation, we start telling ourselves, “I will never be happy again because they died. It’s unfair,” such thoughts fuel self-pity and despair. Emotions grounded in distortion are destructive.
After a loss, illness, breakup, divorce, or a major setback, we may experience either depression or sadness.
But sadness itself is not distorted.
It reflects a natural emotional process and is therefore temporary. Sadness is not tied to a collapse in self-esteem.

Depression is more prolonged; symptoms can intensify. It persists most of the day, nearly every day, for at least two consecutive weeks. Nothing distracts from bleak thoughts, nothing brings joy, life feels colorless—and there is typically a loss of self-worth.
Depression that follows an obvious stressor is sometimes called “reactive.”

test.question: Which symptoms characterize depression as opposed to natural sadness?
answers: A short-term feeling of sadness after an unpleasant event
A temporary dip in interest in favorite activities
A prolonged state of apathy and despair

texts: At times it’s hard to identify a specific stressful event that triggered an episode. Such depressions are often called “endogenous,” because the symptoms seem to arise out of nowhere.
In both reactive and endogenous cases, distorted negative thoughts are key in maintaining the state.
Depression serves no adaptive or productive function; it is one of the most painful forms of suffering.
The hopeful side is the growth that can follow when you work through it.
If depression begins after a particular event, that event acts as a trigger—not the sole cause of the disorder.
The mind was already vulnerable; it only needed a small impulse to set the mechanism in motion.
When something truly bad happens, your emotional state is shaped by your interpretations.
Your feelings are linked to how you perceive what’s happening. Much of the suffering stems from cognitive distortions.

When you correct those distortions, you’ll find it easier to cope with the real problem. In the following chapters, we’ll examine concrete examples that clarify the difference between healthy sadness and depression.

rebuff.title: Technique: Stand Up to Your Inner Critic
rebuff.description: This article presents effective, self-guided methods for strengthening self-esteem. The core technique is learning to counter your inner critic by keeping a structured table of self-critical thoughts, their cognitive distortions, and rational responses. The article emphasizes consistent practice to create meaningful shifts in self-perception and build self-esteem.

texts: We’ve developed a set of simple yet effective techniques to boost self-esteem. These methods are practical and self-guided.
First, it’s crucial to understand that theory alone won’t raise self-esteem.
Lasting change comes from regular practice. Set aside a little time every day—at least at the beginning—until the process becomes a habit.
The first technique teaches you to push back against your inner critic.
Feelings of inadequacy and self-hatred often stem from the inner critic, which constantly undermines your self-esteem.
Negative beliefs like “I’m worthless,” “I’m worse than others,” “Nothing will work out for me,” “Everything is my fault,” “I’m a failure” intensify self-esteem problems and can lead to depression.
To overcome this unhelpful thinking habit, follow this plan:
Learn to notice and write down self-critical thoughts.
Identify the cognitive distortions in those thoughts.
Develop rational responses to build a more realistic, healthy view of yourself—and do this regularly.
You can use the “Automatic Thoughts Diary” in our app for this purpose, or keep notes elsewhere using three columns.
For clarity, we’ll explain the approach using the three-column format.

quote.text: No one can make you feel inferior without your consent.
quote.author: Eleanor Roosevelt

texts: Create a three-column table in any format you like—a notebook, a document on your computer, or a note on your phone. Label the columns:
Critic’s Thought
Cognitive Distortion
Rational Response
In the first column, write down every self-critical thought that comes to mind.
Any time you blame yourself, feel useless, or feel dissatisfied with yourself, ask: “What am I telling myself right now?” and write it down.
For example, if you’re anxious before an exam and think, “I’m so stupid, I’ll definitely fail,” that’s exactly the thought to record.
Be sure to capture your thoughts about yourself—not your feelings. If you write, “I feel awful,” there’s nothing to dispute, because that is simply true in the moment.
In the second column, identify the cognitive distortion in the thought.
Write down which thinking error you notice. There may be one distortion—or two or three.
In the statement “I’m so stupid, I’ll definitely fail,” we can see labeling.
In the thought “I’m incapable, so I’ll be expelled, and I’ll never succeed,” you might find several distortions, such as overgeneralization and catastrophizing.

quote.text: The better I understand myself and my emotional needs, the clearer my grasp of reality becomes—and the fewer fears and misconceptions poison my life.
quote.author: Carl Rogers

texts: And of course, the most important column in our table is the alternative, rational response. This is your real pushback against the inner critic.
Replace the self-critical thought with something realistic and logical—avoid hollow optimism.
Don’t swing to the opposite extreme with a rosy claim that doesn’t ring true.
For example: “I’m the smartest and I’ll ace everything.” That might be true someday, but it’s so far from your original thought that you’re unlikely to believe it—and then it won’t help.
Instead, try to capture what’s actually true.
If your rational response isn’t convincing and realistic to you, it won’t work.
Aim to write an alternative you can genuinely believe.

For instance: “I’m not actually stupid; I have proof of that—I got into university on my own and I’m doing reasonably well. Of course there are times when things don’t work out, but I’m human; I can make mistakes, and that doesn’t make me stupid.

What’s more, I’m preparing for the exam, and I’ll most likely pass at least with a minimum grade; I’ve passed all my other courses. And even if I don’t pass the first time, I can retake it, study well, and pass.”
This kind of rational response is more plausible—and you’re much more likely to believe it.
Use this tool throughout the day, regularly writing down your thoughts and countering destructive beliefs.
Over time, you’ll find it easier to generate rational responses. Most importantly, you’ll notice changes in your mood and in how you relate to yourself.

self_help.title: Through the Dark Days: Self-Help as a Path out of Depression
self_help.description: This article explores the many facets of depression and offers a clear look at evidence-based treatments—including cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) and bibliotherapy—supported by research findings. It aims to equip readers with practical self-help tools and grounded hope for recovery, even in severe cases.

texts: Depression can feel like a dark veil over your mind and life. It drains energy and interest, fuels pessimistic thoughts, and brings a sense of disconnection—sadness about the past and worry about the future. The world can seem dim.

If these lines resonate, you’ve likely encountered depression—personally or through someone close. It’s common enough to be called the “cold” of mental health, yet it can sap meaning and, at times, threaten life.
Still, not every low mood is depression. In the chapters ahead, we’ll explain how to tell the difference.

Let’s start with a definition. Depression (from Latin “depressio”—“to press down”) is described by the World Health Organization as persistent low mood, loss of interest and ability to feel pleasure, guilt or low self-esteem, sleep and appetite changes, fatigue, and problems with concentration.

The good news: depression responds to treatment. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) is a reliable, well-studied approach. With its tools, you can learn skills to shift your mood and manage symptoms on your own.

quote.text: Depression is a “many-sided” disorder; it can smile, it can masquerade as an organic illness—and organic problems, in turn, can dress up as depression.
quote.author: Aaron Beck

texts: Many studies support CBT’s effectiveness. Self-help also plays a crucial role—whether or not you’re seeing a clinician.
For example, research by Dr. Forrest Scogin and colleagues found that bibliotherapy—working with a high-quality self-help book—can rival standard care.
In their trial, participants who read David Burns’s “Feeling Good” showed improvements comparable to outcomes from full psychotherapy or antidepressants.
Scogin and Dr. Christine Jamison randomly assigned people with major depression to two groups.
The first, the “Immediate Bibliotherapy” group, read the book over four weeks.
The second, the “Delayed Bibliotherapy” group, waited a month before starting.
The delay created a control condition, ruling out simple passage of time.
Before starting, all participants completed two measures: the Beck Depression Inventory (self-report) and the Hamilton Rating Scale for Depression (clinician-rated).
After four weeks, reassessment showed marked improvement in the Immediate group: average Beck and Hamilton scores dropped to ~10 or below—within the non-depressed range.
Improvements persisted over the next three months, with no signs of relapse and continued gains.
Meanwhile, scores in the Delayed group remained largely unchanged—evidence the change wasn’t merely time. After receiving the book, they improved similarly.
Taken together, these results highlight the strong potential of self-help in depression; many participants did not need further treatment.
This was one of the early studies validating self-help—but far from the only one.
Research from Scotland reached similar conclusions: well-designed self-help can be surprisingly effective.
In a carefully controlled trial with over 200 people with mild to moderate depression,
participants were assigned to different approaches over several months: some relied solely on antidepressants, others engaged in bibliotherapy.
Those using structured self-help materials improved more than those on medication alone.
These programs were grounded in core CBT principles.
This self-help effect is one reason we created this section.
We want to help you understand what’s happening and offer tools you can use independently.
Step by step, we’ll share essential information about depression and practical techniques to apply on your own.
With these skills, you can start moving out of the cul-de-sac of painful emotions.
Remember: after every storm, the sky clears. Light returns; relief and the desire to live follow.
If you’re struggling now, remember: change is possible—and likely with the right approach, even when today feels heavy.
